title: Surds
content: $ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $ $ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $ $ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

title: Surds

title: Functions
content: Working with Functions # Formulas # $a^m \times a^n = a^{m+n}$ $a^m \div a^n = \dfrac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$ $(a^m)^n = a^{m \times n}$ $(ab)^n = a^nb^n$ $\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^n = \dfrac{a^n}{b^n}$ $a^0=1$ $a^{-n}=\dfrac{1}{a^n}$ $\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^{-n} = \left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^n$ $a^{\frac{m}{n}} =\sqrt[n]{a^m}$ $ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $ $ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $ $ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

title: Combinatorics
content: Standard view $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $

title: Calculus
content:
Standard view Derivative Equivalent integral Comment $y=f(x)^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx}=nf'(x)[f(x)]^{n-1}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n 
eq -1 $ When n = -1 follow the integration rules for $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx$ $y=uv \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}$ $y=\dfrac{u}{v} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{v\dfrac{du}{dx} - u\dfrac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}$ $y=\sin f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\cos f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$ $y=\cos f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -f'(x)\sin f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$ $y=	an f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = 	an f(x) + c$ $y=e^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x) e^{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$ $y=\ln f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ Stictly speaking these integral and derivative formulas are not exact mirrors but are recorded here as presented in the syllabus. The scope of the derivative equation is limited to positive values of f(x) while the integral equation covers both positive and negative values of f(x). The derivative equation could also be rewritten with an absolute value. $y=a^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = (\ln a)f'(x)a^{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation. $y=log _{a} f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ Is this integral expression correct, in particular the absolute value? Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted Derivative Equivalent integral Comment $y=f(x)^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx}=nf'(x)[f(x)]^{n-1}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n 
eq -1 $ When n = -1 follow the integration rules for $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx$ $y=uv \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}$ $y=\dfrac{u}{v} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{v\dfrac{du}{dx} - u\dfrac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}$ $y=\sin f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\cos f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$ $y=\cos f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -f'(x)\sin f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$ $y=	an f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = 	an f(x) + c$ $y=e^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x) e^{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$ $y=\ln f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ Stictly speaking these integral and derivative formulas are not exact mirrors but are recorded here as presented in the syllabus. The scope of the derivative equation is limited to positive values of f(x) while the integral equation covers both positive and negative values of f(x). The derivative equation could also be rewritten with an absolute value. $y=a^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = (\ln a)f'(x)a^{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation. $y=log _{a} f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ Is this integral expression correct, in particular the absolute value? title: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
content: Logarithms and Exponentials # Formulas # $\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$ $\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

eq -1 $ When n = -1 follow the integration rules for $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx$ $y=uv \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}$ $y=\dfrac{u}{v} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{v\dfrac{du}{dx} - u\dfrac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}$ $y=\sin f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\cos f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$ $y=\cos f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -f'(x)\sin f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$ $y=	an f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = 	an f(x) + c$ $y=e^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x) e^{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$ $y=\ln f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ Stictly speaking these integral and derivative formulas are not exact mirrors but are recorded here as presented in the syllabus. The scope of the derivative equation is limited to positive values of f(x) while the integral equation covers both positive and negative values of f(x). The derivative equation could also be rewritten with an absolute value. $y=a^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = (\ln a)f'(x)a^{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation. $y=log _{a} f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ Is this integral expression correct, in particular the absolute value? $y=\sin^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} f(x) + c$ $ y = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{\sqrt{a^2 - (f(x))^2}} $ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$ $y=\cos^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$ $ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}f(x) + c 	ext{ or } -\sin^{-1}f(x) +c$ $ 	ext{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $ $y=\cos^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} }$ $ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c 	ext{ or } -\sin^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} +c$ $ 	ext{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $ $y=	an^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2} dx = \ 	an^{-1} f(x) + c$ $y=	an^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{a} 	an^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} $ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {a^2 + (f(x))^2} dx = \dfrac{1}{a} 	an^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted Derivative Equivalent integral Comment $y=f(x)^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx}=nf'(x)[f(x)]^{n-1}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n

title: Surds
content: $ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $ $ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $ $ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

title: Vectors
content: Standard view $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - \vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $ $ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$ $|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ $|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$ $ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$ $\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$ $\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - \vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $ $ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$ $|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ $|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$ $ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$ $\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$ $\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$

title: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
content: Logarithms and Exponentials # Formulas # $\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$ $\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

The scope of the derivative equation is limited to positive values of f(x) while the integral equation covers both positive and negative values of f(x). The derivative equation could also be rewritten with an absolute value. $y=a^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = (\ln a)f'(x)a^{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation. $y=log _{a} f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ Is this integral expression correct, in particular the absolute value? $y=\sin^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} f(x) + c$ $ y = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{\sqrt{a^2 - (f(x))^2}} $ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$ $y=\cos^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$ $ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}f(x) + c 	ext{ or } -\sin^{-1}f(x) +c$ $ 	ext{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $ $y=\cos^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} }$ $ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c 	ext{ or } -\sin^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} +c$ $ 	ext{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $ $y=	an^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2} dx = \ 	an^{-1} f(x) + c$ $y=	an^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{a} 	an^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} $ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {a^2 + (f(x))^2} dx = \dfrac{1}{a} 	an^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted Derivative Equivalent integral Comment $y=f(x)^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx}=nf'(x)[f(x)]^{n-1}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n 
eq -1 $ When n = -1 follow the integration rules for $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx$ $y=uv \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}$ $ {\Large\int} u \dfrac{dv}{dx} dx=uv-{\Large\int}v \dfrac {du}{dx}dx$ $y=\dfrac{u}{v} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{v\dfrac{du}{dx} - u\dfrac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}$ $y=\sin f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\cos f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$ $y=\cos f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -f'(x)\sin f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$ $y=	an f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = 	an f(x) + c$ $y=e^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x) e^{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$ $y=\ln f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ Stictly speaking these integral and derivative formulas are not exact mirrors but are recorded here as presented in the syllabus. title: Surds
content: $ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $ $ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $ $ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

title: Proof
content: Standard view $ |a| \ge a, \forall \: a \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |a||b| = |ab|, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |a|^2 = a^2, \forall \: a \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |ab| \ge ab, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ a^2 \ge b^2 \iff |a| \ge |b|, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |x| + |y| \ge |x+y|, \forall \; x, y \in \mathbb{R}$ $ \text {even number } 2n, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {odd number } 2n-1, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {square number } n^2, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {X is divisible by p when there exists another number, } p, p \in \mathbb{N}, \text{ if } \exists \; Y, Y \in \mathbb{N} \text { such that } X=pY$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $ |a| \ge a, \forall \: a \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |a||b| = |ab|, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |a|^2 = a^2, \forall \: a \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |ab| \ge ab, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ a^2 \ge b^2 \iff |a| \ge |b|, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |x| + |y| \ge |x+y|, \forall \; x, y \in \mathbb{R}$ $ \text {even number } 2n, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {odd number } 2n-1, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {square number } n^2, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {X is divisible by p when there exists another number, } p, p \in \mathbb{N}, \text{ if } \exists \; Y, Y \in \mathbb{N} \text { such that } X=pY$

title: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
content: Logarithms and Exponentials # Formulas # $\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$ $\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

title: Indices
content: $a^m \times a^n = a^{m+n}$ $a^m \div a^n = \dfrac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$ $(a^m)^n = a^{m \times n}$ $(ab)^n = a^nb^n$ $\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^n = \dfrac{a^n}{b^n}$ $a^0=1$ $a^{-n}=\dfrac{1}{a^n}$ $\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^{-n} = \left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^n$ $a^{\frac{m}{n}} =\sqrt[n]{a^m}$

title: Trigonometric Functions
content:
Trigonometry and Measure of Angles # Formulas # Standard view $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Trigonometric Functions and Identities # Concepts # identity Notes # Reciprocal trigonometric functions Refer formulas below for cosececant (cosec or csc), secant(sec) and cotangent(cot).
Note how $\cot A =  rac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$, which is effectively $ rac{	ext{adjacent}}{	ext{opposite}}$ not $ rac{1}{	an A}$. This is important as tan A is undefined at odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ while cot A is zero. This concept must also be understood when graphing cot A given that cot A has different assymptotes to tan A.
Pythagorean identities An identity is true for all values of the variable, as opposed to an equation which is only true for a certain number(s).
$\cos^2 x+\sin^2 x = 1$ $1+	an^2 x = \sec^2 x$ $\cot^2 x+1 = 	ext{cosec }^2 x$ Note only the first identity appears on the formula sheet. As alternative to memorising the 2nd and 3rd identity above they can be derived by dividing the first indentity by $\cos^2 x$ and $sin^2 x$ respectively.
Complementary angles Complementary angles add up to 90 degrees (vs supsupplementary angles which add up to 180 degrees) Formulas such as $\sin 	heta = \cos (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ are included in formulas below. As an alternative to memorising the complementary angle identities can be derived from a triangle such as below. Worthwhile memorising the sin and cos related formulas at a minimum though.
y=cosec(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty )$, except for multiples of $\pi$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an odd function, -f(x) = f(-x) y=sec(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty)$, except for odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an even function, f(x) = f(-x) y=cot(x)

title: Trigonometric Functions
content:
Trigonometry and Measure of Angles # Formulas # Standard view $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Trigonometric Functions and Identities # Concepts # identity Notes # Reciprocal trigonometric functions Refer formulas below for cosececant (cosec or csc), secant(sec) and cotangent(cot).
Note how $\cot A =  rac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$, which is effectively $ rac{	ext{adjacent}}{	ext{opposite}}$ not $ rac{1}{	an A}$. This is important as tan A is undefined at odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ while cot A is zero. This concept must also be understood when graphing cot A given that cot A has different assymptotes to tan A.
Pythagorean identities An identity is true for all values of the variable, as opposed to an equation which is only true for a certain number(s).
$\cos^2 x+\sin^2 x = 1$ $1+	an^2 x = \sec^2 x$ $\cot^2 x+1 = 	ext{cosec }^2 x$ Note only the first identity appears on the formula sheet. As alternative to memorising the 2nd and 3rd identity above they can be derived by dividing the first indentity by $\cos^2 x$ and $sin^2 x$ respectively.
Complementary angles Complementary angles add up to 90 degrees (vs supsupplementary angles which add up to 180 degrees) Formulas such as $\sin 	heta = \cos (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ are included in formulas below. As an alternative to memorising the complementary angle identities can be derived from a triangle such as below. Worthwhile memorising the sin and cos related formulas at a minimum though.
y=cosec(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty )$, except for multiples of $\pi$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an odd function, -f(x) = f(-x) y=sec(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty)$, except for odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an even function, f(x) = f(-x) y=cot(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty )$, except for multiples of $\pi$ (asymptotes exist at these x-values) range = $(-\infty , \infty )$ It is an odd function, f(x) = f(-x) Formulas # Standard view $\sec A = \dfrac{1}{\cos A}, \cos A 
e 0$ $	ext{cosec } A = \dfrac{1}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$ $\cot A = \dfrac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$ $\cos^2 x+\sin^2 x = 1$ $1+	an^2 x = \sec^2 x$ $\cot^2 x+1 = 	ext{cosec }^2 x$ $	an x = \dfrac{\sin x}{\cos x}, cos x 
e 0$ $\sin 	heta = \cos (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\cos 	heta = \sin (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $	an 	heta = \cot (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\cot 	heta = 	an (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\sec 	heta = 	ext{cosec } (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $	ext{cosec } 	heta = \sec (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sec A = \dfrac{1}{\cos A}, \cos A 
e 0$ $	ext{cosec } A = \dfrac{1}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$ $\cot A = \dfrac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$ $\cos^2 x+\sin^2 x = 1$ $1+	an^2 x = \sec^2 x$ $\cot^2 x+1 = 	ext{cosec }^2 x$ $	an x = \dfrac{\sin x}{\cos x}, cos x 
e 0$ $\sin 	heta = \cos (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\cos 	heta = \sin (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $	an 	heta = \cot (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\cot 	heta = 	an (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\sec 	heta = 	ext{cosec } (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $	ext{cosec } 	heta = \sec (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sec A = \dfrac{1}{\cos A}, \cos A

e 0$ $\sin 	heta = \cos (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\cos 	heta = \sin (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $	an 	heta = \cot (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\cot 	heta = 	an (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $\sec 	heta = 	ext{cosec } (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ $	ext{cosec } 	heta = \sec (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$

title: Indices
content: $a^m \times a^n = a^{m+n}$ $a^m \div a^n = \dfrac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$ $(a^m)^n = a^{m \times n}$ $(ab)^n = a^nb^n$ $\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^n = \dfrac{a^n}{b^n}$ $a^0=1$ $a^{-n}=\dfrac{1}{a^n}$ $\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^{-n} = \left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^n$ $a^{\frac{m}{n}} =\sqrt[n]{a^m}$

title: Differentiation
content: Standard view $v = \dot x = \dfrac{dx}{dt}$ $a = \ddot x = \dfrac{dv}{dt} = \dfrac{d^{2}x}{dt^2}$ $\dfrac{dN}{dt} = kn \text{ is satisfied by } N(t) = Ae^{kt}$ $\dfrac{dN}{dt} = k(N-p) \text{ is satisfied by } N(t) = P + Ae^{kt}$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $v = \dot x = \dfrac{dx}{dt}$ $a = \ddot x = \dfrac{dv}{dt} = \dfrac{d^{2}x}{dt^2}$ $\dfrac{dN}{dt} = kn \text{ is satisfied by } N(t) = Ae^{kt}$ $\dfrac{dN}{dt} = k(N-p) \text{ is satisfied by } N(t) = P + Ae^{kt}$

\cos A \sin B$ $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$ $\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$ $	an(A+B) = \dfrac{	an A + 	an B}{1-	an A 	an B}$ $	an(A-B) = \dfrac{	an A - 	an B}{1+	an A 	an B}$ $\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$ $\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - title: Trigonometric Functions
content: Inverse Trigonometric Functions # Formulas # Standard view $\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x \text{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$ $\tan(\tan^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$ $\tan^{-1}(\tan x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $ $\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $ $\tan^{-1}(-x) = -\tan^{-1}x $ $\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x \text{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$ $\tan(\tan^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$ $\tan^{-1}(\tan x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $ $\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $ $\tan^{-1}(-x) = -\tan^{-1}x $ $\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ Further Trigonometric Identities # Formulas # Standard view $\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$ $\sin(A-B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$ $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$ $\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$ $\tan(A+B) = \dfrac{\tan A + \tan B}{1-\tan A \tan B}$ $\tan(A-B) = \dfrac{\tan A - \tan B}{1+\tan A \tan B}$ $\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$ $\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - \sin^2 A$ $\cos 2A = 2 \cos^2 A -1$ $\cos 2A = 1 - 2 \sin^2 A$ $\tan 2A = \dfrac{2\tan A}{1-\tan^2 A}$ $ \sin A = \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ \cos A = \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ \tan A = \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $\cos A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) + \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)]$ $\cos A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) - \sin(A-B)]$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$ $\sin(A-B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$ $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$ $\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$ $\tan(A+B) = \dfrac{\tan A + \tan B}{1-\tan A \tan B}$ $\tan(A-B) = \dfrac{\tan A - \tan B}{1+\tan A \tan B}$ $\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$ $\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - \sin^2 A$ $\cos 2A = 2 \cos^2 A -1$ $\cos 2A = 1 - 2 \sin^2 A$ $\tan 2A = \dfrac{2\tan A}{1-\tan^2 A}$ $ \sin A = \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ \cos A = \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ \tan A = \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $\cos A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) + \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)]$ $\cos A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) - \sin(A-B)]$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$ $\sin(A-B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$ $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$ $\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$ $\tan(A+B) = \dfrac{\tan A + \tan B}{1-\tan A \tan B}$ $\tan(A-B) = \dfrac{\tan A - \tan B}{1+\tan A \tan B}$ $\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$ $\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - \sin^2 A$ $\cos 2A = 2 \cos^2 A -1$ $\cos 2A = 1 - 2 \sin^2 A$ $\tan 2A = \dfrac{2\tan A}{1-\tan^2 A}$ $ \sin A = \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ \cos A = \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ \tan A = \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$ $\cos A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) + \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)]$ $\cos A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) - \sin(A-B)]$

title: Indices
content: $a^m \times a^n = a^{m+n}$ $a^m \div a^n = \dfrac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$ $(a^m)^n = a^{m \times n}$ $(ab)^n = a^nb^n$ $\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^n = \dfrac{a^n}{b^n}$ $a^0=1$ $a^{-n}=\dfrac{1}{a^n}$ $\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^{-n} = \left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^n$ $a^{\frac{m}{n}} =\sqrt[n]{a^m}$

title: Integration
content:
Standard view $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n 
eq -1 $ $ {\Large\int_{a}^{b}} f(x) dx \approx \dfrac{b-a} {2n} {\Large\{} f(a) + f(b) + 2 {\Large[} f(x_1)+...+f(x_{n-1}){\Large ]} {\Large\}}$ $ 	ext { where } a=x_0 	ext{ and } b=x_n $ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = 	an f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ $ {\Large\int}_b^a f(x)dx = F(b)-F(a) 	ext{, where F(x) is the anti-derivative of f(x)}$ $F'(x) = \dfrac{d}{dx} {\Large\int}_a^x f(t)dt = f(x) 	ext{ (the Fundamental Therom of Calculus)}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n

title: Functions

title: Vectors
content: Introduction to Vectors # Formulas # Standard view $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - \vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $ $ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$ $|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ $|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$ $ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$ $\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$ $\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - \vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $ $ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$ $|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ $|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$ $ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$ $\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$ $\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$

title: Complex Numbers
content:
Standard view $ i = \sqrt{-1}$ $ z = a + ib$ $	ext{ mod z} =|z| = \sqrt{a^2+b^2} $ $	an 	heta = \dfrac{b}{a} 	ext{ where } 	heta 	ext{ equals arg z in interval } (-\pi, \pi] 	ext{Dont confuse with angle of a position vector which ranges from 0 to 360 degrees}$ $z = r (\cos 	heta + i \sin 	heta)$ $ z_1z_2 = r_1 r_2[\cos(	heta_1 + 	heta_2) + i \sin(	heta_1 + 	heta_2)]$ $ \dfrac{z_1}{z_2} = \dfrac{r_1}{ r_2}[\cos(	heta_1 - 	heta_2) + i \sin(	heta_1 - 	heta_2)], z_2 
e 0$ $ z^n = r^n(\cos n 	heta + i \sin n 	heta)$ $ z^{-1} = r^{-1}(\cos 	heta - i \sin 	heta), z 
e 0$ $ z^{-n} = r^{-n}(\cos -n 	heta + i \sin -n 	heta), z

title: Functions

title: Statistical Analysis
content: Standard view $ \text{Mean} = \dfrac{\text{Sum of scores}}{\text{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ \text{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} \text{th score} $ $ \text{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ \text{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ \text{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $\text{An outlier is a score with} $ $ \text { less than } Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \text { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) \text {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx \text { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \text{ for } a \leq x \leq b \text { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \text{Mean} = \dfrac{\text{Sum of scores}}{\text{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ \text{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} \text{th score} $ $ \text{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ \text{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ \text{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $\text{An outlier is a score with} $ $ \text { less than } Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \text { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) \text {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx \text { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \text{ for } a \leq x \leq b \text { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $

title: Trigonometric Functions
content:
Trigonometry and Measure of Angles # Formulas # Standard view $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Trigonometric Functions and Identities # Concepts # identity Notes # Reciprocal trigonometric functions Refer formulas below for cosececant (cosec or csc), secant(sec) and cotangent(cot).
Note how $\cot A =  rac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$, which is effectively $ rac{	ext{adjacent}}{	ext{opposite}}$ not $ rac{1}{	an A}$. This is important as tan A is undefined at odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ while cot A is zero. This concept must also be understood when graphing cot A given that cot A has different assymptotes to tan A.
Pythagorean identities An identity is true for all values of the variable, as opposed to an equation which is only true for a certain number(s).
$\cos^2 x+\sin^2 x = 1$ $1+	an^2 x = \sec^2 x$ $\cot^2 x+1 = 	ext{cosec }^2 x$ Note only the first identity appears on the formula sheet. As alternative to memorising the 2nd and 3rd identity above they can be derived by dividing the first indentity by $\cos^2 x$ and $sin^2 x$ respectively.
Complementary angles Complementary angles add up to 90 degrees (vs supsupplementary angles which add up to 180 degrees) Formulas such as $\sin 	heta = \cos (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ are included in formulas below. As an alternative to memorising the complementary angle identities can be derived from a triangle such as below. Worthwhile memorising the sin and cos related formulas at a minimum though.
y=cosec(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty )$, except for multiples of $\pi$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an odd function, -f(x) = f(-x) y=sec(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty)$, except for odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an even function, f(x) = f(-x) y=cot(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty )$, except for multiples of $\pi$ (asymptotes exist at these x-values) range = $(-\infty , \infty )$ It is an odd function, f(x) = f(-x) Formulas # Standard view $\sec A = \dfrac{1}{\cos A}, \cos A

title: Trigonometric Functions
content: Trigonometric Equations # Formulas # Standard view $a \sin x + b \cos x = r \sin(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \sin x - b \cos x = r \sin(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x + b \sin x = r \cos(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x - b \sin x = r \cos(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $a \sin x + b \cos x = r \sin(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \sin x - b \cos x = r \sin(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x + b \sin x = r \cos(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x - b \sin x = r \cos(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$

title: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
content: Logarithms and Exponentials # Formulas # $\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$ $\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

content: Working with Combinatorics # Formulas # Standard view $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $

eq 0 $ $ P(X=x) = \dfrac{1}{n} 	ext {applies only to uniform proability distributions with n values} $ $ E(X) =\sum xp(x)$ $ E(X) = \mu $ $ \sigma^{2} = Var(X) = \sum(x-\mu)^{2}p(x)$ $ Var(X) = E[(x-\mu)^2]$ $ Var(X) = \sum[x^2p(x)] - \mu^2$ $ Var(X) = E(X^2) - \mu^2$ $ \sigma = \sqrt{Var(X)}$ $ 	ext{Mean} = \dfrac{	ext{Sum of scores}}{	ext{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ 	ext{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} 	ext{th score} $ $ 	ext{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ 	ext{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ 	ext{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $	ext{An outlier is a score with} $ $ 	ext { less than } Q1 - 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ 	ext { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) 	ext {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx 	ext { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} 	ext{ for } a \leq x \leq b 	ext { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ P(E) = \dfrac{n(E)}{n(S)} $ $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) $ $P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)$ $P(\overline{E}) = 1 - P(E)$ $ P(A|B) = \dfrac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} 	ext{, where } P(B)

lowest score} $ $ 	ext{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $	ext{An outlier is a score with} $ $ 	ext { less than } Q1 - 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ 	ext { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) 	ext {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx 	ext { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} 	ext{ for } a \leq x \leq b 	ext { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $ $ 	ext{Bernoulli distribution: } E(X) = p $ $ 	ext{Bernoulli distribution: } VAR(X) = p(1-p) $ $	ext{Binomial distribution}: P(X=r) = ^nC_rp^r(1-p)^{n-r}$ $	ext{Binomial distribution}: X\sim Bin(n,p) $ $ \Rightarrow P(X=x) $ $ =  igl({n \atop x}  igr)p^x(1-p)^{n-x}, x=0,1,...,n$ $ 	ext{binomial distribution: } E(X) = np $ $ 	ext{binmomial distribution: } VAR(X) = np(1-p) $ $ \hat{p} = \dfrac{x}{n} $ $ 	ext{sample proportions: } E(\hat{p}) = p $ $ 	ext{sample proportions: } 	ext{VAR} (\hat{p}) = \dfrac{p(1-p)}{n} $ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $ P(E) = \dfrac{n(E)}{n(S)} $ $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - title: Statistical Analysis
content: Standard view $ \text{Bernoulli distribution: } E(X) = p $ $ \text{Bernoulli distribution: } VAR(X) = p(1-p) $ $\text{Binomial distribution}: P(X=r) = ^nC_rp^r(1-p)^{n-r}$ $\text{Binomial distribution}: X\sim Bin(n,p) $ $ \Rightarrow P(X=x) $ $ = \bigl({n \atop x} \bigr)p^x(1-p)^{n-x}, x=0,1,...,n$ $ \text{binomial distribution: } E(X) = np $ $ \text{binmomial distribution: } VAR(X) = np(1-p) $ $ \hat{p} = \dfrac{x}{n} $ $ \text{sample proportions: } E(\hat{p}) = p $ $ \text{sample proportions: } \text{VAR} (\hat{p}) = \dfrac{p(1-p)}{n} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \text{Bernoulli distribution: } E(X) = p $ $ \text{Bernoulli distribution: } VAR(X) = p(1-p) $ $\text{Binomial distribution}: P(X=r) = ^nC_rp^r(1-p)^{n-r}$ $\text{Binomial distribution}: X\sim Bin(n,p) $ $ \Rightarrow P(X=x) $ $ = \bigl({n \atop x} \bigr)p^x(1-p)^{n-x}, x=0,1,...,n$ $ \text{binomial distribution: } E(X) = np $ $ \text{binmomial distribution: } VAR(X) = np(1-p) $ $ \hat{p} = \dfrac{x}{n} $ $ \text{sample proportions: } E(\hat{p}) = p $ $ \text{sample proportions: } \text{VAR} (\hat{p}) = \dfrac{p(1-p)}{n} $

title: Trigonometric Functions
content:
Trigonometry and Measure of Angles # Formulas # Standard view $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Trigonometric Functions and Identities # Concepts # identity Notes # Reciprocal trigonometric functions Refer formulas below for cosececant (cosec or csc), secant(sec) and cotangent(cot).
Note how $\cot A =  rac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$, which is effectively $ rac{	ext{adjacent}}{	ext{opposite}}$ not $ rac{1}{	an A}$. This is important as tan A is undefined at odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ while cot A is zero. This concept must also be understood when graphing cot A given that cot A has different assymptotes to tan A.
Pythagorean identities An identity is true for all values of the variable, as opposed to an equation which is only true for a certain number(s).
$\cos^2 x+\sin^2 x = 1$ $1+	an^2 x = \sec^2 x$ $\cot^2 x+1 = 	ext{cosec }^2 x$ Note only the first identity appears on the formula sheet. As alternative to memorising the 2nd and 3rd identity above they can be derived by dividing the first indentity by $\cos^2 x$ and $sin^2 x$ respectively.
Complementary angles Complementary angles add up to 90 degrees (vs supsupplementary angles which add up to 180 degrees) Formulas such as $\sin 	heta = \cos (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ are included in formulas below. As an alternative to memorising the complementary angle identities can be derived from a triangle such as below. Worthwhile memorising the sin and cos related formulas at a minimum though.
y=cosec(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty )$, except for multiples of $\pi$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an odd function, -f(x) = f(-x) y=sec(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty)$, except for odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an even function, f(x) = f(-x) y=cot(x)
domain = $(-\infty , \infty )$, except for multiples of $\pi$ (asymptotes exist at these x-values) range = $(-\infty , \infty )$ It is an odd function, f(x) = f(-x) Formulas # Standard view $\sec A = \dfrac{1}{\cos A}, \cos A

	heta)$ $	ext{cosec } 	heta = \sec (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ Inverse Trigonometric Functions # Formulas # Standard view $\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x 	ext{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x 	ext{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$ $	an(	an^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$ $	an^{-1}(	an x) = x 	ext{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $ $\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $ $	an^{-1}(-x) = -	an^{-1}x $ $\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x 	ext{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x 	ext{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$ $	an(	an^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$ $	an^{-1}(	an x) = x 	ext{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $ $\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $ $	an^{-1}(-x) = -	an^{-1}x $ $\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ Further Trigonometric Identities # Formulas # Standard view $\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$ $\sin(A-B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$ $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$ $\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$ $	an(A+B) = \dfrac{	an A + 	an B}{1-	an A 	an B}$ $	an(A-B) = \dfrac{	an A - 	an B}{1+	an A 	an B}$ $\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$ $\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - \sin^2 A$ $\cos 2A = 2 \cos^2 A -1$ $\cos 2A = 1 - 2 \sin^2 A$ $	an 2A = \dfrac{2	an A}{1-	an^2 A}$ $ \sin A = \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2} 	ext{, where t }=	an \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ \cos A = \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2} 	ext{, where t }=	an \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ 	an A = \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2} 	ext{, where t }=	an \dfrac{A}{2}$ $\cos A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) + \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)]$ $\cos A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) - \sin(A-B)]$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$ $\sin(A-B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$ $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$ $\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$ $	an(A+B) = \dfrac{	an A + 	an B}{1-	an A 	an B}$ $	an(A-B) = \dfrac{	an A - 	an B}{1+	an A 	an B}$ $\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$ $\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - title: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
content: Logarithms and Exponentials # Formulas # $\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$ $\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$ $\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

title: Statistical Analysis
content: Descriptive Statistics and Bivariate Data Analysis # Formulas # Standard view $ \text{Mean} = \dfrac{\text{Sum of scores}}{\text{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ \text{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} \text{th score} $ $ \text{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ \text{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ \text{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $\text{An outlier is a score with} $ $ \text { less than } Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \text { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \text{Mean} = \dfrac{\text{Sum of scores}}{\text{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ \text{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} \text{th score} $ $ \text{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ \text{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ \text{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $\text{An outlier is a score with} $ $ \text { less than } Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \text { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ Random Variables # Formulas # Standard view $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) \text {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx \text { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \text{ for } a \leq x \leq b \text { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) \text {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx \text { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \text{ for } a \leq x \leq b \text { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $

title: Vectors
content: Standard view $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - \vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $ $ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$ $|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ $|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$ $ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$ $\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$ $\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$ $|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ $|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$ $ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$ $\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$ $\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$

title: Trigonometry
content: Standard view $\sin^2nx = \dfrac{1}{2}(1-\cos 2nx)$ $\cos^2nx = \dfrac{1}{2}(1+\cos 2nx)$ $a \sin x + b \cos x = r \sin(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \sin x - b \cos x = r \sin(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x + b \sin x = r \cos(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x - b \sin x = r \cos(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sin^2nx = \dfrac{1}{2}(1-\cos 2nx)$ $\cos^2nx = \dfrac{1}{2}(1+\cos 2nx)$ $a \sin x + b \cos x = r \sin(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \sin x - b \cos x = r \sin(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x + b \sin x = r \cos(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x - b \sin x = r \cos(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin^2nx = \dfrac{1}{2}(1-\cos 2nx)$ $\cos^2nx = \dfrac{1}{2}(1+\cos 2nx)$ $a \sin x + b \cos x = r \sin(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \sin x - b \cos x = r \sin(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x + b \sin x = r \cos(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$ $a \cos x - b \sin x = r \cos(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$

\begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$ $|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ $|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$ $ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$ $\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$ $\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - title: Statistical Analysis
content: The Binomial Distribution # Formulas # Standard view $ \text{Bernoulli distribution: } E(X) = p $ $ \text{Bernoulli distribution: } VAR(X) = p(1-p) $ $\text{Binomial distribution}: P(X=r) = ^nC_rp^r(1-p)^{n-r}$ $\text{Binomial distribution}: X\sim Bin(n,p) $ $ \Rightarrow P(X=x) $ $ = \bigl({n \atop x} \bigr)p^x(1-p)^{n-x}, x=0,1,...,n$ $ \text{binomial distribution: } E(X) = np $ $ \text{binmomial distribution: } VAR(X) = np(1-p) $ $ \hat{p} = \dfrac{x}{n} $ $ \text{sample proportions: } E(\hat{p}) = p $ $ \text{sample proportions: } \text{VAR} (\hat{p}) = \dfrac{p(1-p)}{n} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \text{Bernoulli distribution: } E(X) = p $ $ \text{Bernoulli distribution: } VAR(X) = p(1-p) $ $\text{Binomial distribution}: P(X=r) = ^nC_rp^r(1-p)^{n-r}$ $\text{Binomial distribution}: X\sim Bin(n,p) $ $ \Rightarrow P(X=x) $ $ = \bigl({n \atop x} \bigr)p^x(1-p)^{n-x}, x=0,1,...,n$ $ \text{binomial distribution: } E(X) = np $ $ \text{binmomial distribution: } VAR(X) = np(1-p) $ $ \hat{p} = \dfrac{x}{n} $ $ \text{sample proportions: } E(\hat{p}) = p $ $ \text{sample proportions: } \text{VAR} (\hat{p}) = \dfrac{p(1-p)}{n} $

title: Combinatorics
content: Standard view $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $

eq 0 $ $ P(X=x) = \dfrac{1}{n} 	ext {applies only to uniform proability distributions with n values} $ $ E(X) =\sum xp(x)$ $ E(X) = \mu $ $ \sigma^{2} = Var(X) = \sum(x-\mu)^{2}p(x)$ $ Var(X) = E[(x-\mu)^2]$ $ Var(X) = \sum[x^2p(x)] - \mu^2$ $ Var(X) = E(X^2) - \mu^2$ $ \sigma = \sqrt{Var(X)}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ P(E) = \dfrac{n(E)}{n(S)} $ $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) $ $P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)$ $P(\overline{E}) = 1 - P(E)$ $ P(A|B) = \dfrac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} 	ext{, where } P(B)

Formulas # Standard view $ 	ext{Mean} = \dfrac{	ext{Sum of scores}}{	ext{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ 	ext{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} 	ext{th score} $ $ 	ext{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ 	ext{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ 	ext{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $	ext{An outlier is a score with} $ $ 	ext { less than } Q1 - 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ 	ext { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ 	ext{Mean} = \dfrac{	ext{Sum of scores}}{	ext{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ 	ext{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} 	ext{th score} $ $ 	ext{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ 	ext{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ 	ext{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $	ext{An outlier is a score with} $ $ 	ext { less than } Q1 - 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ 	ext { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ Random Variables # Formulas # Standard view $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) 	ext {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx 	ext { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} 	ext{ for } a \leq x \leq b 	ext { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) 	ext {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx 	ext { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} 	ext{ for } a \leq x \leq b 	ext { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $ The Binomial Distribution # content: Standard view $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $
