title: Trigonometric Functions
content:
Trigonometry and Measure of Angles # Formulas # Standard view $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin A=\dfrac{opp}{hyp}$ $\cos A=\dfrac{adj}{hyp}$ $	an A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$ $\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $ $c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$ $A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$ $\sin (180^\circ - 	heta) = \sin 	heta $ $\cos (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - \cos 	heta $ $	an (180 ^\circ - 	heta) = - 	an 	heta $ $l=r	heta$ $A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 	heta$ Trigonometric Functions and Identities # Concepts # identity Notes # Reciprocal trigonometric functions Refer formulas below for cosececant (cosec or csc), secant(sec) and cotangent(cot).
Note how $\cot A =  rac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \sin A 
e 0$, which is effectively $ rac{	ext{adjacent}}{	ext{opposite}}$ not $ rac{1}{	an A}$. This is important as tan A is undefined at odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ while cot A is zero. This concept must also be understood when graphing cot A given that cot A has different assymptotes to tan A.
Pythagorean identities An identity is true for all values of the variable, as opposed to an equation which is only true for a certain number(s).
$\cos^2 x+\sin^2 x = 1$ $1+	an^2 x = \sec^2 x$ $\cot^2 x+1 = 	ext{cosec }^2 x$ Note only the first identity appears on the formula sheet. As alternative to memorising the 2nd and 3rd identity above they can be derived by dividing the first indentity by $\cos^2 x$ and $sin^2 x$ respectively.
Complementary angles Complementary angles add up to 90 degrees (vs supsupplementary angles which add up to 180 degrees) Formulas such as $\sin 	heta = \cos (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ are included in formulas below. As an alternative to memorising the complementary angle identities can be derived from a triangle such as below. Worthwhile memorising the sin and cos related formulas at a minimum though.
y=cosec(x)

domain = $(-\infty , \infty)$, except for odd multiples of $ rac{\pi}{2}$ range = $(-\infty , -1] \cup [1, \infty) $ It is an even function, f(x) = f(-x) y=cot(x)

	heta)$ $	ext{cosec } 	heta = \sec (90^{\circ} - 	heta)$ Inverse Trigonometric Functions # Formulas # Standard view $\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x 	ext{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x 	ext{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$ $	an(	an^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$ $	an^{-1}(	an x) = x 	ext{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $ $\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $ $	an^{-1}(-x) = -	an^{-1}x $ $\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x 	ext{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$ $\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x 	ext{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$ $	an(	an^{-1} x) = x 	ext{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$ $	an^{-1}(	an x) = x 	ext{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ $\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $ $\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $ $	an^{-1}(-x) = -	an^{-1}x $ $\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ Further Trigonometric Identities # Formulas # Standard view $\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$ $\sin(A-B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$ $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$ $\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$ $	an(A+B) = \dfrac{	an A + 	an B}{1-	an A 	an B}$ $	an(A-B) = \dfrac{	an A - 	an B}{1+	an A 	an B}$ $\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$ $\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - \sin^2 A$ $\cos 2A = 2 \cos^2 A -1$ $\cos 2A = 1 - 2 \sin^2 A$ $	an 2A = \dfrac{2	an A}{1-	an^2 A}$ $ \sin A = \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2} 	ext{, where t }=	an \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ \cos A = \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2} 	ext{, where t }=	an \dfrac{A}{2}$ $ 	an A = \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2} 	ext{, where t }=	an \dfrac{A}{2}$ $\cos A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) + \cos(A+B)]$ $\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - content: Standard view $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - \vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $ $ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$ $|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ $|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; title: Combinatorics
content: Working with Combinatorics # Formulas # Standard view $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $

title: Integration
content:
Standard view $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n 
eq -1 $ $ {\Large\int_{a}^{b}} f(x) dx \approx \dfrac{b-a} {2n} {\Large\{} f(a) + f(b) + 2 {\Large[} f(x_1)+...+f(x_{n-1}){\Large ]} {\Large\}}$ $ 	ext { where } a=x_0 	ext{ and } b=x_n $ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = 	an f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ $ {\Large\int}_b^a f(x)dx = F(b)-F(a) 	ext{, where F(x) is the anti-derivative of f(x)}$ $F'(x) = \dfrac{d}{dx} {\Large\int}_a^x f(t)dt = f(x) 	ext{ (the Fundamental Therom of Calculus)}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n

eq -1 $ $ {\Large\int_{a}^{b}} f(x) dx \approx \dfrac{b-a} {2n} {\Large\{} f(a) + f(b) + 2 {\Large[} f(x_1)+...+f(x_{n-1}){\Large ]} {\Large\}}$ $ 	ext { where } a=x_0 	ext{ and } b=x_n $ Volumes formed by rotation about the x-axis = $V=\pi \int_a^b y^2 dx$ Volumes formed by rotation about the y-axis = $V=\pi \int_a^b x^2 dy$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = 	an f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ $ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ $ {\Large\int}_b^a f(x)dx = F(b)-F(a) 	ext{, where F(x) is the anti-derivative of f(x)}$ $F'(x) = \dfrac{d}{dx} {\Large\int}_a^x f(t)dt = f(x) 	ext{ (the Fundamental Therom of Calculus)}$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$ $ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}f(x) + c 	ext{ or } -\sin^{-1}f(x) +c$ $ 	ext{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $ $ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c 	ext{ or } -\sin^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} +c$ $ 	ext{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2} dx = \ 	an^{-1} f(x) + c$ $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {a^2 + (f(x))^2} dx = \dfrac{1}{a} 	an^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ 	ext{ where } n

title: Proof
content: Proof by Mathematical Induction # The Nature of Proof # Formulas # Standard view $ |a| \ge a, \forall \: a \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |a||b| = |ab|, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |a|^2 = a^2, \forall \: a \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |ab| \ge ab, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ a^2 \ge b^2 \iff |a| \ge |b|, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |x| + |y| \ge |x+y|, \forall \; x, y \in \mathbb{R}$ $ \text {even number } 2n, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {odd number } 2n-1, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {square number } n^2, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {X is divisible by p when there exists another number, } p, p \in \mathbb{N}, \text{ if } \exists \; Y, Y \in \mathbb{N} \text { such that } X=pY$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $ |a| \ge a, \forall \: a \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |a||b| = |ab|, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |a|^2 = a^2, \forall \: a \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |ab| \ge ab, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ a^2 \ge b^2 \iff |a| \ge |b|, \forall \: a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ $ |x| + |y| \ge |x+y|, \forall \; x, y \in \mathbb{R}$ $ \text {even number } 2n, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {odd number } 2n-1, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {square number } n^2, \forall \: n \in \mathbb{N}$ $ \text {X is divisible by p when there exists another number, } p, p \in \mathbb{N}, \text{ if } \exists \; Y, Y \in \mathbb{N} \text { such that } X=pY$ Further Proof by Mathematical Induction #

title: Statistical Analysis
content:
Probability and Discrete Probability Distributions # Formulas # Standard view $ P(E) = \dfrac{n(E)}{n(S)} $ $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) $ $P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)$ $P(\overline{E}) = 1 - P(E)$ $ P(A|B) = \dfrac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} 	ext{, where } P(B) 
eq 0 $ $ P(X=x) = \dfrac{1}{n} 	ext {applies only to uniform proability distributions with n values} $ $ E(X) =\sum xp(x)$ $ E(X) = \mu $ $ \sigma^{2} = Var(X) = \sum(x-\mu)^{2}p(x)$ $ Var(X) = E[(x-\mu)^2]$ $ Var(X) = \sum[x^2p(x)] - \mu^2$ $ Var(X) = E(X^2) - \mu^2$ $ \sigma = \sqrt{Var(X)}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ P(E) = \dfrac{n(E)}{n(S)} $ $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) $ $P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)$ $P(\overline{E}) = 1 - P(E)$ $ P(A|B) = \dfrac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} 	ext{, where } P(B) 
eq 0 $ $ P(X=x) = \dfrac{1}{n} 	ext {applies only to uniform proability distributions with n values} $ $ E(X) =\sum xp(x)$ $ E(X) = \mu $ $ \sigma^{2} = Var(X) = \sum(x-\mu)^{2}p(x)$ $ Var(X) = E[(x-\mu)^2]$ $ Var(X) = \sum[x^2p(x)] - \mu^2$ $ Var(X) = E(X^2) - \mu^2$ $ \sigma = \sqrt{Var(X)}$ Proofs required Items where proofs required are highlighted $ P(E) = \dfrac{n(E)}{n(S)} $ $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) $ $P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)$ $P(\overline{E}) = 1 - P(E)$ $ P(A|B) = \dfrac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} 	ext{, where } P(B) 
eq 0 $ $ P(X=x) = \dfrac{1}{n} 	ext {applies only to uniform proability distributions with n values} $ $ E(X) =\sum xp(x)$ $ E(X) = \mu $ $ \sigma^{2} = Var(X) = \sum(x-\mu)^{2}p(x)$ $ Var(X) = E[(x-\mu)^2]$ $ Var(X) = \sum[x^2p(x)] - \mu^2$ $ Var(X) = E(X^2) - \mu^2$ $ \sigma = \sqrt{Var(X)}$ Descriptive Statistics and Bivariate Data Analysis # Formulas # Standard view $ 	ext{Mean} = \dfrac{	ext{Sum of scores}}{	ext{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ 	ext{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} 	ext{th score} $ $ 	ext{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ 	ext{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ 	ext{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $	ext{An outlier is a score with} $ $ 	ext { less than } Q1 - 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ 	ext { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ 	ext{Mean} = \dfrac{	ext{Sum of scores}}{	ext{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $ $ 	ext{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} 	ext{th score} $ $ 	ext{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $ $ 	ext{Range = highest score - lowest score} $ $ 	ext{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $ $	ext{An outlier is a score with} $ $ 	ext { less than } Q1 - 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ 	ext { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 	imes IQR $ $ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $ Random Variables # Formulas # Standard view $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) 	ext {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx 	ext { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} 	ext{ for } a \leq x \leq b 	ext { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) 	ext {(for continuous probability distributions})$ $F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx 	ext { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$ $P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$ $P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$ $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} 	ext{ for } a \leq x \leq b 	ext { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$ $z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $ The Binomial Distribution # Formulas # Standard view $ 	ext{Bernoulli distribution: } E(X) = p $ $ 	ext{Bernoulli distribution: } VAR(X) = p(1-p) $ $	ext{Binomial distribution}: P(X=r) = ^nC_rp^r(1-p)^{n-r}$ $	ext{Binomial distribution}: X\sim Bin(n,p) $ $ \Rightarrow P(X=x) $ $ =  igl({n \atop x}  igr)p^x(1-p)^{n-x}, x=0,1,...,n$ $ 	ext{binomial distribution: } E(X) = np $ $ 	ext{binmomial distribution: } VAR(X) = np(1-p) $ $ \hat{p} = \dfrac{x}{n} $ $ 	ext{sample proportions: } E(\hat{p}) = p $ $ 	ext{sample proportions: } 	ext{VAR} (\hat{p}) = \dfrac{p(1-p)}{n} $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ 	ext{Bernoulli distribution: } E(X) = p $ $ 	ext{Bernoulli distribution: } VAR(X) = p(1-p) $ $	ext{Binomial distribution}: P(X=r) = ^nC_rp^r(1-p)^{n-r}$ $	ext{Binomial distribution}: X\sim Bin(n,p) $ $ \Rightarrow P(X=x) $ $ =  igl({n \atop x}  igr)p^x(1-p)^{n-x}, x=0,1,...,n$ $ 	ext{binomial distribution: } E(X) = np $ $ 	ext{binmomial distribution: } VAR(X) = np(1-p) $ $ \hat{p} = \dfrac{x}{n} $ $ 	ext{sample proportions: } E(\hat{p}) = p $ $ 	ext{sample proportions: } 	ext{VAR} (\hat{p}) = \dfrac{p(1-p)}{n} $

title: Vectors

\vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $ $ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $ $\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $ $\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $ $\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $ $ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $ $ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $ $ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $ $ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $ $ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$ $ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$ $\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$ $\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $ $ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $ $ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $ $ \vec{AB} - title: Combinatorics
content: Standard view $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $ Formula sheet Items on formula sheet are highlighted $P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$ $^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$ $0! = 1$ $^n P_n = n!$ $^n P_0 = 1$ Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$ $^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$ $(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$ $ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $ $ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $ $ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $ $ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $ $ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $ $ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $
